questions.prompt: In BG 6.1, what distinguishes a true sannyasi from one who merely abstains from activities?
choices: Complete withdrawal from all duties and social responsibilities
Abandoning family life regardless of spiritual advancement
Performing prescribed duties without attachment to fruits
Accepting formal vows and wearing traditional renunciate dress
questions.feedback: Anashritah karma-phalam (unattached to work-fruits) karyam karma karoti (performs prescribed work)-such person is sannyasi and yogi, not one abandoning agni (fire ceremonies) and kriya (activities). Why this matters: External renunciation doesn't define spiritual status-consciousness quality determines standing. True sannyasi/yogi performs duties without fruit-attachment-internal detachment enables external engagement. Cultivate consciousness transformation not lifestyle withdrawal-desireless work-performance makes authentic renunciate not ceremony-cessation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.2, what is the actual relationship between yoga and sannyasa?
choices: What is called sannyasa is actually yoga; both require desire-renunciation
Yoga and sannyasa are completely separate paths for different people
Sannyasa must be completed before one can begin practicing yoga
Yoga is for householders while sannyasa is only for renunciates
questions.feedback: What they call sannyasa (renunciation) know as yoga-na hyasannyasta-sankalpah yogi bhavati (one doesn't become yogi without renouncing sankalpas/desires). Why this matters: Yoga IS sannyasa when properly understood-both require identical internal state of desire-transcendence enabling Krsna-consciousness. External differences (active vs withdrawn) less significant than internal similarity-both achieve desireless consciousness through different expressions. Don't artificially separate yoga-sannyasa-consciousness unifies seemingly divergent paths.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.3, what different means are prescribed for the beginning practitioner versus the advanced yogi?
choices: Both use the same practice of constant meditation in isolation
Beginner practices physical postures; advanced practices breath control
Beginner studies philosophy; advanced transcends all scriptural knowledge
Beginner uses work as means; advanced uses tranquility as means
questions.feedback: For muni (sage) desiring yoga-aroha (ascending), karma is karanam (means); for one yoga-arudha (ascended), shamah (tranquility) is karanam. Yogaruruksu (beginner ascending) needs karma-yoga (engaged action) for purification; yogarudha (advanced ascended) needs shama (tranquility) for deepening. Different stages require different approaches-beginners purify through action, advanced stabilize through stillness. Apply stage-appropriate practice-karma-yoga for purification-phase, dhyana-yoga for realization-phase, recognizing spiritual path's progressive developmental nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.4, when is one declared to be established in yoga (yogarudha)?
choices: When one renounces all activities and lives in complete seclusion
When one masters all eight stages of ashtanga-yoga perfectly
When one develops supernatural powers through yogic perfection
When attached to neither desires nor actions
questions.feedback: When neither sarva-sankalpah (all desires) nor karmashu (in actions) attached-yogarudha (ascended in yoga) is declared. Yogarudha simultaneously transcends desires AND actions' binding power-not by avoiding but by performing without attachment. Sankalpah (mental formations) and karmashu (activities) both transcended through consciousness-shift not behavior-modification. Aim for engaged transcendence-active participation without volitional investment, achieving freedom through consciousness-quality not activity-quantity reduction.

questions.prompt: What fundamental principle does BG 6.5 teach about spiritual advancement?
choices: Spiritual progress comes automatically through divine grace alone
One must elevate oneself by oneself; the self is friend or enemy
The material mind must be completely destroyed for liberation
One should depend entirely on the guru's mercy for all advancement
questions.feedback: Uddharet atmana atmanam (one should elevate self by self)-atma (self) is both mitra (friend) and vairee (enemy) depending on self-mastery. Self must elevate self through disciplined practice-no external agent can substitute for personal striving. Atma becomes friend when controlled or enemy when uncontrolled-same entity, different relationship based on self-governance. Engage vigorous self-improvement-guru guides but individual must do work, God facilitates but won't override free will, establishing personal responsibility for spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.6, how does Srila Prabhupada explain the self becoming friend or enemy?
choices: Friend when naturally peaceful; enemy when born restless
Friend with proper education; enemy without training
Friend through good fortune; enemy through bad karma
Friend when conquered through discipline; enemy when unconquered
questions.feedback: Self conquered for one who conquered self becomes mitra (friend); for unconquered, self acts as shatru-vat (like enemy) in enmity. Conquered self controlled through discipline becomes ally enabling spiritual progress; unconquered self following every impulse sabotages spiritual goals like enemy. Not external enemy but internal lack of self-governance creates suffering. Practice self-control-not self-rejection but self-governance, converting inner chaos into inner ally through disciplined spiritual practice.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.7, what dualities does the self-conquered person transcend?
choices: Birth and death, bondage and liberation, ignorance and knowledge
Cold and heat, pleasure and pain, honor and dishonor
Past and future, memory and anticipation, regret and anxiety
Right and wrong, good and evil, virtue and vice
questions.feedback: Jitatmanah prashantasya (for self-conquered peaceful one)-same-sighted in sheeta-ushna (cold-heat), sukha-duhkha (pleasure-pain), mana-apamana (honor-dishonor). Natural equanimity from self-conquest-jitatmanah (self-mastered) achieves prashantatva (peace) enabling sama-drishti (equal vision) toward all dualities. Not suppression but transcendence-dualities don't disturb because consciousness anchored beyond their reach. Cultivate self-mastery producing natural peace-enables spontaneous equanimity without forced neutralization.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.8, what vision does Srila Prabhupada explain characterizes the yogi satisfied through knowledge and realization?
choices: Seeing clod, stone, and gold equally as Krsna's energy
Perceiving no differences between any material objects whatsoever
Seeing all material objects as worthless and rejecting them completely
Valuing spiritual objects while despising all material things
questions.feedback: Jnana-vijnana-trptatma (satisfied by knowledge-realization)-sees sama (equally) loshta-ashma-kanchana (clod-stone-gold). Yuktatma (established yogi) sees sama not by ignoring differences but by transcending material value-hierarchy-clod/stone/gold differ functionally but equal spiritually as Krsna's energy. Not material leveling but spiritual transcendence beneath functional differences. Develop sama-drishti-recognize material varieties' practical utility while transcending attachment-hierarchy, seeing all as Krsna's energy regardless of material value-gradations.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.9, what quality of vision distinguishes the most elevated person?
choices: Equal-minded toward friend, enemy, neutral, mediator, hateful, relative, virtuous, sinful
Ability to judge spiritual advancement levels accurately in all beings
Recognizing one's own superiority while remaining externally humble
Seeing all people as identical and treating everyone exactly the same way
questions.feedback: Suhrn-mitra-ari-udasina-madhyastha-dveshya-bandhu-sadhu-api-ca-papesu-sama-buddhih (equal-minded toward friend-enemy-neutral-mediator-hateful-relative-virtuous-sinful)-vishishyate (is distinguished). Nine categories of relationships all met with sama-buddhi (equal intelligence) by yogi. Not ignoring differences but transcending reactive consciousness-honors functional distinctions without internal turbulence. Practice transcendent pragmatism-maintain appropriate responses while cultivating equal-minded consciousness underneath varied behaviors.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.10, what should the yogi do constantly?
choices: Perform elaborate fire sacrifices and Vedic rituals regularly
Practice physical postures and breathing exercises throughout the day
Fix the mind in meditation while secluded, self-controlled, desireless, non-possessive
Study scripture and attend philosophical discussions with devotees
questions.feedback: Yogi constantly (satatam) should yunjita (engage) citta (consciousness) staying viviktadeshena (in solitary place), yatatma (self-controlled), nirasir (without desires), aparigraha (non-possessive). Why this matters: Satatam (constantly) yunjita-continuous practice not sporadic attempts, comprehensive lifestyle supporting integrated consciousness. Not segmented spirituality but persistent consciousness-orientation toward Supreme. Cultivate continuous practice maintaining spiritual focus as constant backdrop throughout activities.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.11, what practical requirements does Krsna specify for the yoga seat?
choices: Expensive meditation equipment purchased from traditional yoga suppliers only
Elevated platform positioned where others can observe collective practice
Any comfortable chair or cushion suitable for extended sitting periods
Clean place with firm seat neither too high nor too low
questions.feedback: Shucau deshe (in clean place) establishing firm asana (seat)-neither ati-ucchritam (too high) nor ati-nicham (too low). Practical prerequisites-clean location, stable seat, moderate height-support meditation without guaranteeing it. Too much attention produces distraction through perfectionism; too little produces distraction through discomfort. Establish reasonable practice-conditions-adequate cleanliness/stability/comfort enabling focus without obsessive environment-engineering, balancing external support with internal priority.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.12, what does Srila Prabhupada explain is the actual purpose of making the mind one-pointed?
choices: To achieve temporary stress relief and improved mental health
For self-purification through controlled consciousness and senses
For enhanced productivity and success in material endeavors
To develop supernatural powers and impress others with abilities
questions.feedback: Tatraikagram manah kritva (making mind one-pointed there)-controlling citta (consciousness) and indriyas (senses), practice yoga for atma-vishuddhaye (self-purification). Ekagrata (one-pointedness) with controlled consciousness-senses for atma-vishuddhaye-meditation as spiritual discipline not therapeutic technique. Aim is consciousness-transformation purifying false ego, not temporary stress-reduction. Approach meditation as purification-practice-tolerating discomfort of confronting conditioned mind, seeking permanent transformation not temporary relief from material pressure.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.13, how should the yogi position the body and focus consciousness?
choices: Any comfortable position that allows extended sitting without pain
Walking meditation while maintaining continuous awareness of steps
Body-head-neck aligned motionless, consciousness fixed on Krsna
Lying comfortably while visualizing the transcendental form peacefully
questions.feedback: Samam kaya-shiro-grivam (body-head-neck evenly aligned) holding acalam (motionless)-practicing brahmacharya (celibacy) with citta (consciousness) on ekam (one) Krsna. Physical alignment (samam upright posture, acalam stillness) supports but doesn't substitute for mental focus-citta fixed ekam on Krsna. Brahmacharya (celibacy/sense-control) prevents distraction. Maintain proper posture while prioritizing consciousness-discipline-body's stillness supports mind's one-pointedness but can't replace it, physical foundation enabling mental focus.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.13-14, what prerequisites does Srila Prabhupada explain enable meditation?
choices: Complete isolation from all human contact
Expensive equipment and traditional location
Years of prior physical yoga practice
Peace, fearlessness, celibacy, controlled mind, with Krsna as goal
questions.feedback: Prashanta-atma (peaceful self) vigata-bhih (without fear) brahmachari-vrate sthitah (established in celibacy-vow)-controlling manas (mind), yukta (engaged) asita (should sit) mat-parah (Me as supreme goal). Prerequisites-prashanta (peace), vigata-bhih (fearlessness), brahmacharya (celibacy), controlled mind-enable mat-parah meditation. Techniques serve devotional goal-meditation isn't impersonal training but Krsna-connection. Infuse technique with devotion, recognizing practice requires proper method and devotional consciousness.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.15, how does Srila Prabhupada explain the true nature of yogic perfection (shanti/nirvana-parama)?
choices: As mat-samstha (abiding in Krsna), not cessation but connection
As complete abandonment of all activity and relationships
As developing mystic powers and supernatural abilities
As cessation of all consciousness in an impersonal void state
questions.feedback: Yunjann evam (thus engaging) atmanam (self) yogi niyata-manah (controlled mind) shantim (peace) nirvana-paramam (supreme liberation) mat-samstha (abiding in Me) attains. Why this matters: Shanti and nirvana-parama defined as mat-samstha (abiding in Krsna)-not impersonal void but personal relationship with Supreme. Liberation isn't cessation but connection-ending material existence for transcendental existence. Seek positive liberation-Krsna-relationship, redefining freedom from absence-of-bondage to presence-of-devotion.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.16, what extremes does Srila Prabhupada warn prevent yoga success?
choices: Excessive or insufficient eating, sleeping, recreation
Too much solitude or constant social engagement
Extreme asceticism or complete sense indulgence
Too much study or complete ignorance of scripture
questions.feedback: Na ati-ashnatas (not overeating) nor ati-svapnasya (oversleeping) yoga bhavati (becomes), nor ekantam (complete) anashnatah (fasting) nor jagratah (waking). Yoga requires yukta (balance) not ati (excess)-eating/sleeping/activity/rest all moderated. Neither over-indulgence (ati-ashnatas) nor over-restriction (ekantam anashnatas) supports practice. Practice moderate lifestyle-sufficient eating/sleeping enabling practice without excess/deficiency, recognizing spiritual life requires practical sustainability through balanced habits not impressive extremism producing burnout.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.17, what is the result of regulated habits in all domains?
choices: Complete independence from all bodily needs and requirements
Yoga becomes the destroyer of all suffering
Automatic entrance into samadhi without further practice needed
Guaranteed achievement of mystic siddhis and supernatural powers
questions.feedback: Yuktahara-viharasya (balanced eating-recreation) yukta-ceshtasya (balanced activity) karma-su yukta-svapna-avabodhasya (balanced sleep-waking)-yoga becomes duhkha-ha (destroyer of suffering). Yukta (balanced) in all domains-eating/recreation/work/sleep-enables yoga destroying duhkha. Not ascetic deprivation but intelligent moderation-enjoying necessities without excess. Maintain yukta-ahara-vihara-regulate material life intelligently supporting spiritual practice, avoiding both indulgent excess and ascetic deprivation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.18, when does Srila Prabhupada explain one is yukta?
choices: When achieving temporary concentration during meditation
When receiving initiation from a spiritual master
When consciousness remains controlled, steady in self, desireless
When developing ability to sit motionless for hours
questions.feedback: When citta (consciousness) niruddham (controlled) sthitah (remains) atmani (in self) eva nispriha (without desires) from sarva-kamat (all material desires)-then yuktah (established) iti ucyate (is said). Yukta (established yogi) maintains consciousness sthita (steady) atmani nispriha (desireless) toward all kamat-not temporary concentration but stable realization. Occasional meditation-success differs from established transcendence. Aim for stability-consistent consciousness-quality persisting beyond formal practice.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.19, what analogy does Srila Prabhupada use to illustrate the steadiness of a controlled mind?
choices: Like a lamp in a windless place that doesn't flicker
Like a deep ocean undisturbed by surface waves
Like a mountain unmoved by strong winds and storms
Like a tree with deep roots unshaken by tempests
questions.feedback: Yatha dipo nivata-sthah (as lamp in windless place) na ingate (doesn't flicker)-yoga-yukta (engaged yogi) whose citta (consciousness) controlled practicing atma-yoga (self-meditation). Controlled consciousness like lamp in windless place-steady unflickering focus indicating stability-quality not intensity-quantity. Restless struggling differs from steady focus-former indicates insufficient preparation, latter indicates ripening practice. Cultivate steadiness-patient consistent practice developing natural stability, measuring meditation-quality by steadiness not intensity.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.20-21, how does the perfected yogi experience happiness?
choices: By remembering past material enjoyments from a detached perspective
Through complete unconsciousness and absence of all perception
In transcendental bliss beyond the senses, perceived through purified intelligence
Through continued but purified engagement with material sense objects and experiences
questions.feedback: Where citta niruddham (consciousness controlled) yoga-sevatah (through yoga-practice)-where atmanam atmana pashyan (seeing self through self) atmani (in self) tushyati (is satisfied). This happiness is atindriyam (beyond senses) and buddhi-grahyam (grasped by purified intelligence)-transcendental bliss perceived through spiritual realization not sensory experience. Why this matters: Atmana pashyan atmanam-self validating through self-perception not external feedback, achieving fulfillment from inner realization. Cultivate self-validation-measure advancement through direct self-perception, not external markers (titles/positions/followers), achieving independence from social validation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.20-23, what confusion does Srila Prabhupada warn about when comparing material pleasure with transcendental happiness?
choices: Thinking happiness requires suppression of all material desires
Pursuing yoga for mystic powers rather than realization
Seeking happiness through external achievements and possessions
Believing material and spiritual happiness are equivalent
questions.feedback: Sukham atantikam (unlimited happiness) that buddhi-grahyam (intelligence grasps) atindriyam (beyond senses)-established knowing this na chalati (doesn't deviate) from tattvatah (from truth). Atindriyas sukham (transcendental happiness) buddhi-grahyam (grasped by purified intelligence) beyond sense-perception. Atantikam (unlimited/permanent) versus indriya-sukham (sense-based pleasure) which is anta-vantam (limited/temporary). Transcend spiritual hedonism-seeking permanent transcendental realization not temporary sublime experiences.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.22, what characterizes the supreme gain (param labham) in yoga?
choices: Recognition and fame as advanced spiritual practitioner among followers
Gaining which, one considers no other gain greater and remains unshaken by sorrow
Accumulation of mystic powers impressing ordinary people with abilities
Achievement of perfect health and extended longevity in material body
questions.feedback: Gaining which na aparam (no other) gain considers punyasam (greater)-established in which na duhkhena guruna api (not by heavy sorrow) vicalyate (is shaken). Having gained Krsna-connection considers it param labham (supreme gain)-nothing superior exists. Na vicalyate (unshaken) guruna duhkhena api-commitment persists through adversity. Develop unwavering commitment-establish Krsna-connection as non-negotiable life-priority maintained through favorable/unfavorable circumstances equally, testing spiritual maturity through adversity-persistence not prosperity-enthusiasm.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.23, how does Srila Prabhupada define yoga and its practice?
choices: Union with Brahman through intellectual speculation
Physical fitness through proper diet and exercise
Severing sorrow's connection through determined, joyful practice
Mystical perfection through severe austerities
questions.feedback: Duhkha-samyoga-viyogam (severing sorrow-connection) yoga-samjnita (called yoga)-practice with nishcayena (determination) yoga without sannyasa vishada (abandoning sad-heartedness). Yoga defined as duhkha-samyoga-viyoga-requires nishcayena (firm determination) without vishada (sad-heartedness/depression). Not grim determination but joyful resolve-enthusiasm without emotionalism. Cultivate determined consistency-neither passive compliance nor emotional fluctuation, maintaining steady committed practice through clear conviction.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.24, what does Srila Prabhupada explain must be completely abandoned at the root level for yoga success?
choices: All external activities and social engagements with family members
Desires born from mental formations (sankalpa), restraining senses by mind
The physical body's needs for food, sleep, and basic maintenance
All philosophical study and intellectual understanding of scripture
questions.feedback: Sankalpa-prabhavan kaman (desires born from sankalpa-mental formations) tyaktva sarvan (abandoning all) asheshatah (completely)-restraining indriya-gramam (sense-group) manasa (by mind) from sarvatah (all sides). Address sankalpa-prabhavan (desire-source)-mental formations generating desires-not just controlling expressions. Tyaktva sarvan asheshtah-thorough not superficial. Manasa control indriya-gramam-mind-level work enabling sense-level control. Work at root-level-transform sankalpa generating desires, not just restrain indriyas expressing desires.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.25, how should one approach the process of mind control?
choices: Gradually, by intelligence held firmly, thinking of nothing but the self
Through forceful suppression of all thoughts using willpower alone
By completely abandoning all practice until inspiration naturally arises
Through intense weekend retreats achieving immediate transformation rapidly
questions.feedback: Shanai-shanai (gradually) uparamet (should cease) buddhi-dhrita-grihtaya (by intelligence held firmly)-fixing manas (mind) on atman (self) na kinchit api cintayet (should think nothing else). Shanai-shanai (gradually/slowly) approach-reasonable expectations preventing discouragement. Buddhi-dhrita (firmly grasped intelligence) guiding process through patient intelligent progression. Accept gradual development-measure progress over months/years not days/weeks, maintaining patient consistent practice without frustration from immediate-result expectations, trusting process over time.
